questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isograft

 

An isograft is a type of graft where the donor and the recipient are genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of graft has the lowest risk of rejection because the donor and recipient have the same genetic makeup, which means their tissues are immunologically compatible.

 

Types of Grafts:

 

Option A. Allograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of the same species but have different genotypes.
  • Examples: Organ transplants between two different individuals (e.g., kidney transplant from one person to another non-twin individual).

 

Option B. Autograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are the same person.
  • Examples: Skin grafts taken from one part of the body and transplanted to another part of the same individual's body.

 

Option C. Isograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft between two individuals who are genetically identical, such as identical twins.
  • Examples: Organ or tissue transplants between identical twins.

 

Option D. Xenograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of different species.
  • Examples: Transplantation of animal tissues or organs into humans, such as pig heart valves used in human heart surgery.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Autografts are grafts in which both the donor and the recipient are the same person.
  • Isografts are grafts that occur between donors and recipients who share the same genotype. An isograft is a graft from an identical twin
  • Allografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of the same species but of a different genotype.
  • Xenografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of different species.

questions.text: All of the following are contraceptive methods used post-coitus except? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Danazol

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post coitus contraception means emergency contraception
  • Danazol is an androgen similar to testosterone and is used in endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B CuT200: CUT200 is an intrauterine contraceptive device which can be used in emergency contraception (up to 120 h/ 5 days post coitus)

 

Option C. RU486: RU486 is Mifepristone. This is an anti-progesterone and can be used for emergency contraception)

 

Option D. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: Combined high dose OCPs – used as Yuzpe’s regime, is a method of post-coital/ emergency contraception 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury and his serum K+ level was found to be 5.5 mEq/L. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Becomes more positive

 

Explanation

 

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause a shift in the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value, increased cell excitability, and impairments in membrane potential changes.

 

Hyperkalemia can affect the resting membrane potential of cells, including neurons and muscle cells, in the following ways:

 

  1. Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value.
  2. Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli.
  3. Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials.
  4.  Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No change: Incorrect. Changes in extracellular potassium concentrations directly impact the resting membrane potential.

 

Option B. Becomes more negative: Incorrect. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration results in depolarization (more positive resting membrane potential), not hyperpolarization.

 

Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative: Incorrect. While complex fluctuations can occur under dynamic conditions, primarily, hyperkalemia causes a persistent depolarization (more positive shift) without an initial opposite change.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hyperkalemia, as seen in patients with severe muscle injury, the resting membrane potential becomes more positive due to decreased potassium efflux, leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells. This can affect the normal function of these cells, potentially leading to complications such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: In case of a prior history of neural tube defects, women in the preconception period should be advised to take: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Folic acid

 

Folic acid is crucial for women in the preconception period, especially for those with a prior history of neural tube defects (NTDs). Neural tube defects are serious birth defects that affect the brain and spinal cord. The neural tube forms early in pregnancy, and folic acid, a B vitamin, plays a significant role in preventing these defects.

 

For women with a prior history of NTDs, the recommended dose of folic acid is higher than usual—4 milligrams (mg) per day. This higher dose is necessary because these women are at a greater risk of having another pregnancy affected by NTDs. Ideally, folic acid supplementation should begin at least 3 months before conception to maximize its protective effect.

 

This intervention is considered a form of primary prevention because it is aimed at preventing the occurrence of NTDs in pregnancies where the risk is already known due to a previous history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron is important during pregnancy, but it does not have a direct role in preventing neural tube defects. It is typically recommended for preventing anemia.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D is crucial for bone health and immune function, but it is not specifically related to the prevention of neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Calcium: Calcium is vital for bone health, particularly for the developing fetus, but like iron and vitamin D, it is not involved in the prevention of neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women with a prior history of neural tube defects, folic acid supplementation at a dose of 4 milligrams per day should be started at least 3 months before conception as a form of primary prevention.

choices.text: Fibrinoid necrosis
Gangrenous necrosis
Fat necrosis

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrinoid necrosis

 

Immune responses that affect blood vessels, such in polyarteritis nodosa, typically display fibrinoid necrosis.

 

Grossly, PAN lesions appear as minute beaded nodules at the bifurcations and branching of vessel segments.

 

Antigen-antibody complexes accumulate in the blood arteries in several immunological diseases. Complement activation brought on by these complexes causes type III hypersensitivity, which damages cells. This leads to leakage of fibrin out of the blood vessel, giving a pinkish appearance around the blood vessels.

 

Fibrinoid necrosis is characterized by deposition of fibrin-like material which has the staining properties of fibrin. It is encountered in various examples of immunologic tissue injury (e.g., in immune complex vasculitis, autoimmune diseases, Arthus reaction etc.), arterioles in hypertension, peptic ulcer etc.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gangrenous necrosis: Typically associated with ischemic necrosis of limbs or bowel, not primarily a feature of vascular inflammation.

 

Option C. Fat necrosis: Occurs in adipose tissue due to trauma or pancreatitis, not related to vascular injury.

 

Option D. Caseous necrosis: Characteristic of tuberculosis, involving granulomatous inflammation with a cheese-like appearance, unrelated to PAN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the following conditions:

 

  • SLE
  • Libman-sacks endocarditis
  • Arthus reaction
  • Serum sickness
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Malignant hypertension

questions.text: A young woman wants to take the post-coital pill. Which one should be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LNG

 

The post-coital pill, also known as emergency contraception, is used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. The preferred choice for emergency contraception, particularly in many countries including India, is Levonorgestrel (LNG).

 

LNG (Levonorgestrel): Available under brand names such as the "easy pill," it contains 1.5 mg of levonorgestrel. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse to effectively prevent pregnancy. It is a single-dose regimen that is well-tolerated and has fewer side effects compared to other methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Norethisterone: This is not used for emergency contraception. It is primarily used in other hormonal treatments, such as for menstrual disorders.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Estrogen alone is not used for emergency contraception due to the risk of side effects and its lower efficacy compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option D. Estrogen + Progesterone (Yuzpe regimen): Although this method can be used for emergency contraception, it is not preferred due to the higher incidence of side effects like nausea and vomiting. This method involves taking a high dose of estrogen and progesterone and repeating it after 12 hours, which is less convenient and less well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred emergency contraceptive pill is Levonorgestrel (LNG), to be taken as a single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

choices.text: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.text: In a case of blunt abdominal trauma, a 30-year-old male patient presents with pelvic fracture, minimal urine output on catheterization, and no blood at the meatus. The radiological image shows extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity. What is the preferred next step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparotomy

 

The pattern of contrast extravasation in the given image suggests intraperitoneal bladder rupture, which is caused by a blow or fall on the distended bladder. The preferred next step of management, in this case, is laparotomy for repair and bladder drainage (suprapubic and urethral catheter). Hence, the correct option is C) Laparotomy. Laparoscopic approaches are also now being used.

 

Laparotomy is the preferred next step in management when a patient presents with of extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity (intra-peritoneal rupture), as it may lead to chemical peritonitis. This suggests a significant bladder injury, and a laparotomy is necessary to assess the extent of the injury and provide appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy may be considered in cases of pelvic fracture and suspected urethral rupture. Absence of blood at urethral meatus rules out urethral rupture.

 

Option B. Perurethral catheterization: Perurethral catheterization may not be the best choice in this situation. It is preferred in extra-peritoneal ruptures.

 

Option D. Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy: Pelvic packing and percutaneous nephrostomy may be considered in certain cases of pelvic trauma but are not the primary management options when there is evidence of intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

choices.text: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital
Perform more small incision cataract surgery
To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots
To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of progressive vision loss is scheduled for cataract surgery under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment. Which of the following is NOT an accurate guideline or inclusion criterion for cataract surgery within this national program? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots

 

Explanation:

 

To do surgery in rural area with makeshift hospital/Ots is not advisable, suggests conducting surgeries in temporary setups or less equipped facilities, typically in rural areas. This is considered unsafe and against the guidelines because such environments cannot guarantee the sterility and safety standards required for surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital: This refers to the standard protocol where patients identified as needing cataract surgery are instructed to come to a base or main hospital that is equipped for such procedures. This ensures that surgeries are performed in a controlled, sterile environment with appropriate medical facilities and staff.

 

Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery (SICS): This statement encourages the adoption of small incision cataract surgery, which is a modern technique that allows for quicker recovery times and potentially fewer complications than traditional methods. It is particularly advantageous in resource-limited settings because it does not require expensive machinery like phacoemulsification units.

 

Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area: This approach involves transporting patients from rural and remote areas to fixed, well-equipped surgical facilities, typically located in urban or suburban centers. This ensures all patients receive high-quality care in facilities that meet national and international health and safety standards.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The primary aim of these guidelines is to ensure that all surgeries, particularly sensitive ones like cataract surgery, are performed in environments that uphold the highest standards of medical care and patient safety. The emphasis is on using modern surgical techniques and ensuring that all procedures are carried out in well-equipped, permanent medical facilities to minimize risks and enhance recovery outcomes. The standard guideline includes:

 

  1. Village Register (Linelisting of cases)
  2. Screening camps
  3. Transport of cases to Base hospital
  4. Free surgery – fixed facility surgery approach (Reach in approach at base Hospitals preferred over Reach out approach as camp mode)
  5. Follow up of cases (for this camp mode is preferred)

choices.text: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
Chediak-Higashi syndrome
Essential thrombocythemia

questions.text: CD-59 is involved in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

 

CD-59 is involved in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

 

PNH is an acquired red cell membrane disorder characterized by chronic intravascular hemolysis. The absence of two proteins, decay accelerating factor (DAF, CD55) and membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis (MIRL, CD59), makes RBCs overly sensitive to complement's lytic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: This is a genetic disorder affecting the immune and nervous systems, characterized by abnormalities in lysosomal trafficking, leading to abnormal neutrophil function and albinism.

 

Option C. Essential thrombocythemia: A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by the excessive production of platelets without a known cause.

 

Option D. Primary myelofibrosis: Another myeloproliferative disorder where the bone marrow is progressively replaced with fibrous tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CD-59 deficiency is specific to PNH and does not play a role in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, essential thrombocythemia, or primary myelofibrosis.

questions.text: A young child complained to his parents that he was touched inappropriately by a neighbor.  On examination by a doctor in the OPD, he complained of pain when touched in the perianal area. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine pirate. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Option D. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Educational Objective

 

The Barberio test detects the presence of spermine from semen by forming yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate, making it the correct test for the described scenario.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic ear infection presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal lobe abscess

 

The clinical vignette with the given CT image points to a diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess that is most likely to have developed as a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

 

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication of CSOM.

 

Localizing symptoms of temporal lobe abscess -

 

  1. Nominal aphasia. If abscess involves dominant hemisphere, i.e. left hemisphere in right-handed persons, patient fails to tell the names of common objects such as key, pen, etc. but can demonstrate their use.
  2. Homonymous hemianopia. This is due to pressure on the optic radiations. Visual field, opposite to the side of the lesion, is lost. It can be elicited by confrontation test, by standing in front of the patient and comparing his visual field with that of the examiner, or by perimeter. The defect is usually in the upper, but sometimes in the lower quadrants.
  3. Contralateral motor paralysis. In the usual upward spread of abscess, the face is involved first followed by the arm and leg. Inward spread, towards the internal capsule, involves the leg first followed by the arm and the face.
  4. Epileptic fits. Involvement of uncinate gyrus causes hallucinations of taste, and smell and involuntary smacking movements of lips and tongue. Generalized fits may occur.

 

CT brain is the investigation of choice. Brain abscess is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion in imaging studies.

 

Management:

 

  1. IV antibiotics (usually third generation cephalosporin +/- metronidazole) are started. Aminoglycosides are added if pseudomonas infection is suspected. Culture and sensitivity of ear swabs can guide antibiotic therapy.
  2.  Raised intracranial tension can be lowered by dexamethasone, 4 mg i.v. 6 hourly or mannitol 20% in doses of 0.5 g/kg body weight
  3. Surgical: Abscess drainage of the temporal lobe abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy for CSOM is the definitive management in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebellar abscess: Would likely present with different symptoms, including severe dizziness, balance problems, and coordination difficulties.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Usually presents with more diffuse cerebral symptoms and different radiological features.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Characterized by severe headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia, with different findings on lumbar puncture and imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of chronic ear infections that requires prompt recognition and aggressive treatment to prevent further neurological damage and potential life-threatening complications.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 90, 91

questions.text: Which influenza virus was responsible for the 2009 pandemic? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) H1N1

 

The 2009 influenza pandemic, commonly referred to as the "swine flu" pandemic, was caused by the H1N1 influenza A virus. This virus emerged in Mexico and quickly spread worldwide, causing widespread illness and leading to a global pandemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H5N1: Known as the "bird flu" virus.

 

  • Year: First identified in 1997 in Hong Kong.
  • Impact: Primarily affects birds but can infect humans, causing severe respiratory illness.

 

Option C. H5N7: This subtype of influenza is not known to have caused any major pandemics or widespread outbreaks in humans.

 

Option D. H3N2: This subtype of influenza A virus is known to cause seasonal flu epidemics but was not responsible for the 2009 pandemic.

 

  • Year: H3N2 was involved in the 1968 influenza pandemic, known as the "Hong Kong flu."

 

Educational Objective:

 

Influenza Pandemics

 

SWINE FLU, H1N1 → 2009, Mexico

BIRD FLU, H7N9 → 2013, China

BIRD FLU, H5N1 → 1997, Hong Kong

BIRD FLU, H10N3 → 2021, China

questions.text: A 27-year-old male came with complaints of asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions and hair loss as given below. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

 

The patient presents with several key clinical features: asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on the trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions (condyloma lata), and patchy hair loss. The patchy hair loss, described as "moth-eaten alopecia," is a characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. These signs are strongly indicative of an infection caused by Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for syphilis. The presence of condyloma lata and the specific type of alopecia observed are classical clues pointing towards this diagnosis.

 

DD of Patchy Alopecia – Alopecia areata, Tinea capitis, Trichotillomania, and Secondary Syphilis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malassezia furfur: This organism is associated with conditions like pityriasis versicolor and seborrheic dermatitis, neither of which typically present with the described combination of symptoms, particularly the moth-eaten alopecia and condyloma lata.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus can cause skin infections and folliculitis, it does not typically cause the type of patchy alopecia or the other systemic symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Microsporum canis: This is a dermatophyte that causes tinea capitis, which can lead to patchy hair loss. However, tinea capitis would be associated with scaly patches and other signs of fungal infection rather than the systemic features like condyloma lata seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "moth-eaten alopecia" is a key diagnostic feature of secondary syphilis, and Treponema pallidum is the causative organism.

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.text: During resuscitation, when is the given position? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present

 

This is the recovery position, indicated in post-op patients who are awake or drowsy or unconscious with pulse and breathing present to prevent aspiration of any secretions or vomit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent: Means the patient is in cardiac arrest and requires immediate resuscitation measures.

 

Option B. Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent: This is respiratory arrest and rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to maintain breathing of patient.

 

Option D. Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present: This seems very theoretical because with a lack of circulation, breathing isn’t feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for an unconscious patient who has a pulse and is breathing to prevent aspiration and maintain airway patency.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a feature of delayed blood transfusion reaction?  (INICET MAY 2024)

  1. Increased unconjugated bilirubin
  2. Cola colored urine after 2 hours
  3. Increased LDH
  4. Failure of rise of hemoglobin after transfusion
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3 and 4

 

Delayed blood transfusion reactions typically occur more than 24 hours after the initiation of a blood transfusion. These reactions can result from various immune-mediated processes, often involving the destruction of transfused red blood cells. The features of delayed blood transfusion reactions include:

 

  • Increased unconjugated bilirubin: This occurs due to hemolysis, where the breakdown of red blood cells releases hemoglobin that is converted into unconjugated bilirubin.
  • Increased LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in many tissues, including red blood cells. When red blood cells are destroyed, LDH levels in the blood increase.
  • Failure of rise of hemoglobin after transfusion: Despite the transfusion, the hemoglobin level does not increase as expected because the transfused red blood cells are being destroyed.

 

Incorrect Statement 

 

Statement 2 Cola colored urine after 2 hours: Cola-colored urine shortly after transfusion is indicative of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, not a delayed reaction. Delayed hemolytic reactions typically present with cola-colored urine after several days, not within 2 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delayed blood transfusion reactions occur more than 24 hours after transfusion and are characterized by increased unconjugated bilirubin, increased LDH, and failure of hemoglobin levels to rise. Immediate cola-colored urine indicates an acute reaction, not a delayed one.

questions.text: A patient cannot identify objects but she can see the color, texture, shape. What is the site of the lesion? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipital area

 

 

The patient’s symptoms indicate a condition known as visual agnosia, where there is an inability to recognize objects despite having intact vision for color, texture, and shape. This suggests that the primary visual cortex (area 17) is functioning properly, but the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) are affected.

 

  • Occipital Area: The occipital lobe, specifically Brodmann areas 18 and 19, are responsible for the higher-order processing of visual information. Lesions in these areas can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot interpret or recognize visual stimuli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial parietal area: The medial parietal area is not primarily  involved in visual recognition.

 

Option B. Lateral parietal area: The lateral parietal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Option C. Infra temporal area: The infra temporal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesions in the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) of the occipital lobe can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot identify objects.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to hospital with pain in great toe. His serum uric acid was raised. He was given a medication to relieve the pain and inflammation and after that, he was put on a drug for long term treatment of gout. Which of the following drug increases the excretion of uric acid in urine? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Probenecid

 

  • Probenecid increases the excretion of uric acid in urine by inhibiting the tubular reabsorption of uric acid. It is a uricosuric drug.

  • Examples of other uricosuric drugs are Sulfinpyrazone, Benzbromarone and Lesinurad.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colchicine: Colchicine is used primarily for the treatment of acute gout attacks. It works by inhibiting granulocyte migration and reducing inflammation, but it does not increase the excretion of uric acid.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid.

 

Option D. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is also a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, similar to allopurinol. It reduces the production of uric acid by inhibiting xanthine oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Probenecid is a uricosuric drug that increases the excretion of uric acid in the urine by inhibiting its reabsorption in the renal tubules. This makes it effective for the long-term management of gout by lowering serum uric acid levels. Other drugs like colchicine, allopurinol, and febuxostat have different mechanisms of action and do not increase uric acid excretion in the urine.

questions.text: A patient presented with features as given in the image below.What is the likely  diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Arsenic

 

The image shows characteristic features of arsenic poisoning, including Mees' lines (Aldrich Mees lines) on the nails, which are transverse white lines seen in cases of heavy metal poisoning, particularly arsenic and thallium. The skin findings, such as hyperpigmentation and "raindrop" appearance, are also commonly associated with chronic arsenic exposure. Even though thallium poisoning can also present with similar nail changes, arsenic is the best answer unless alopecia is specifically noted, which is more common in thallium poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mercury: Mercury poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as tremors, psychological disturbances, and gingivitis, not with the distinct Mees' lines and skin changes seen here.

 

Option C. Lead: Lead poisoning commonly affects the nervous system and presents with symptoms like abdominal pain, constipation, and lead lines on the gums (Burton’s lines), not the nail and skin changes shown in the image.

 

Option D. Copper: Copper toxicity, such as Wilson's disease, typically presents with liver, neurological symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes, not with Mees' lines or the described skin pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mees' lines and raindrop pigmentation of the skin are classic signs of arsenic poisoning. In the absence of alopecia, arsenic is the preferred diagnosis over thallium.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The clinic history along with microscopic image is suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Gram-negative, intracellular, cocci, usually seen in pairs (diplococci) with the adjacent sides flattened (typically kidney-shaped); (Looks like two coffee beans kissing).

 

In urethral discharge, it is predominately found within the polymorphs.

 

Gonococci do not contain capsules (meningococci do).

 

Virulence factors -

 

  • Pili: Pili mediate attachment to mucosal cell surfaces and also are antiphagocytic. Piliated gonococci are usually virulent, whereas nonpiliated strains are avirulent.
  • Lipooligosaccharides (LOS)
  • Outer membrane proteins and Opa proteins eg. Porin A: mediates invasion of the epithelial cells.
  • IgA protease hydrolyzes secretory IgA, which could otherwise block the attachment of Neisseria gonorrheae to the mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan and not a gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes urethritis but is an obligate intracellular bacterium that does not show the gram-negative diplococcus morphology.

 

Option D. Gardnerella: Associated with bacterial vaginosis and presents as gram-variable coccobacilli, not gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of gram-negative, intracellular, kidney-shaped diplococci in urethral discharge is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhea, a common causative agent of sexually transmitted infections resulting in urethritis.

questions.text: In this case, a young boy is exhibiting symptoms of reduced mood, decreased energy, and diminished engagement with his environment. He has refrained from eating for the past week and his thoughts include phrases like "I have lost my mind. I am deceased. How can I consume food?". What is the specific delusion in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nihilistic delusion

 

Nihilistic delusion (delusion of negation, Cotard syndrome): Patients may deny the existence of their body, their mind, or the world in general. For example, a patient with severe depression claimed that all his internal organs have rotted.

 

Here, the best answer is Nihilistic delusion rather than Cotard syndrome because the question has specifically asked the type of delusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypochondriacal delusion: Hypochondriacal delusion is an illness anxiety disorder. It is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances.

 

Option D. Bizarre delusion: Scientifically impossible and culturally implausible (un-understandable). For example, a patient claimed that aliens stole his heart and lungs, and now he is living without those organs.

questions.text: What is the type of inheritance shown in the Image: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AD

 

Notice that the disease is present in all 3 generations. It is being transmitted from affected father to his daughter and son. Also, it is being transmitted from affected mother to her progeny. So, it is autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AR (Autosomal Recessive): Typically, AR inheritance shows disease in siblings, not across multiple generations, and both parents must be carriers.

 

Option C. XLD (X-linked Dominant): Affected fathers would transmit the disease to all daughters but not sons, and affected mothers can transmit to both sons and daughters.

 

Option D. XLR (X-linked Recessive): More common in males; females are typically carriers unless they have two affected X chromosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The presence of the disease in all three generations and transmission from both affected fathers and mothers to their progeny indicates autosomal dominant (AD) inheritance.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the ECG shown below?(INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mobitz type 2 block


The ECG shows bradycardia with regular, constant PR intervals in the conducted beats and intermittently dropped QRS complexes, which are indicative of Mobitz type 2 block. This type of atrioventricular block is characterized by:

 

  • Constant PR interval in the conducted beats
  • Intermittent non-conducted P waves (dropped QRS complexes)

 

This distinguishes Mobitz type 2 block from other types of heart block:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>200 ms) but all P waves are followed by QRS complexes. This is not observed in the given ECG.

 

Option B. Third degree heart block: Complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, with no relationship between them. The given ECG does not show this pattern.

 

Option C. Wenckebach heart block (Mobitz type 1): Progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a QRS complex is dropped. The given ECG shows constant PR intervals, not progressively increasing.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mobitz type 2 block is identified by a constant PR interval with intermittently non-conducted P waves. Recognizing this pattern is crucial for appropriate management, as Mobitz type 2 can progress to complete heart block and often requires a pacemaker.

questions.text: Skull of a dead person was found during investigation. Police asked the relatives to bring the photo of deceased. Which of the following method can be used for identification of dead body? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superimposition.

 

Craniofacial superimposition is a technique used in the field of forensic anthropology to assist in the analysis of an unknown skull. The photograph of the missing person is superimposed on the photograph of the skull of a missing person. It is an exclusionary evidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthropometry (Bertillon’s System, Bertillonage)

 

  1. The science of measuring the body parts constitutes Bertillon’s system  or  anthropometry.
  2. It is only applicable in adults. After the age of 21 years the skeleton stops growing and hence the measurements of various parts of the body remain constant.
  3. It is also assumed that no two people will have bones of identical dimensions.

 

Option B. Dactylography:

 

  • The study of fingerprints for identification.
  • Useful for identifying living persons or well-preserved bodies but not applicable for skeletal remains.

 

Option D. DNA Fingerprinting:

 

  • Analysis of DNA to identify individuals.
  • Highly accurate but requires biological samples such as hair, blood, or tissue, which may not be available with skeletal remains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superimposition is the appropriate method for identifying a skull using a photograph of the deceased, by comparing anatomical features to establish a match.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida is in labor. She has a repeated urge to pass urine and has premature bearing down. On examination there is infra-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart is heard on the lateral side. What is the most likely presentation/ position? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occipito-posterior

 

Explanation:

 

Occipito-posterior:

 

  • History:
    • Early rupture of membranes.
    • Frequent filling of bladder.
    • Premature bearing down.
  • Abdominal Examination:
    • Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening, which indicates that the fetus is not positioned centrally in the uterus.
    • Grips: The fetal head is un-engaged, which is often the case with occipito-posterior positions.
    • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds (FHS) are heard on the flanks, suggesting that the fetus is lying posteriorly.
  • Vaginal Examination:
    • An elongated bag of membranes.
    • The posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint.
    • The anterior fontanelle is more easily felt due to deflexion of the fetal head.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Brow: The brow presentation involves partial extension of the fetal head. The presenting diameter is larger, leading to a more difficult labor. However, this would not typically present with infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option B. Knee: A knee presentation is a form of breech presentation where the knees are the presenting part. It is rare and would not cause infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option D. Right dorso-anterior: This position involves the fetus's back being to the mother's right and anterior. It would not cause infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart sounds like the occipito-posterior position does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The occipito-posterior position in labor is characterized by infra-umbilical flattening, frequent filling of the bladder, premature bearing down, and fetal heart sounds heard on the lateral side.

 

 

Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute leukemia

 

  • Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale centers, named after Moritz Roth.
  • Roth spots are classically described in and are considered as pathognomonic of Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis with the yellowish-white centre consisting of a focus of embolic infection.
  • They are commonly seen in other conditions as well.
  • In leukaemia, the white center typically represents fibrin-platelet plugs.
  • Roth's spots are composed of coagulated fibrin, including platelets, focal ischemia, inflammatory infiltrate, infectious organisms, or neoplastic cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uveal melanoma: A primary cancer of the eye involving the iris, ciliary body, or choroid, not typically associated with Roth spots.

 

Option C. Uveal lymphoma: A rare type of eye cancer affecting the uvea, not commonly associated with Roth spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roth's spots may be seen in -

 

1. Leukemia

2. Diabetes

3. Subacute bacterial endocarditis

4. Hypertensive retinopathy

5. HIV retinopathy

6. Systemic lupus erythematosus

7. Anemia

8. Pre-eclampsia

9. Anoxi

questions.text: What is the dose of carbetocin used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 100 mcg

 

  • 100 mcg of carbetocin is used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • The use of carbetocin (100 mcg, IM/IV) is recommended for the prevention of PPH.
  • It is a long-acting synthetic analog of oxytocin which is stable at room temperature (unlike oxytocin which needs the cold chain to be maintained.
  • To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the following uterotonic agents:
    • Oxytocin (10 IU - IM/IV)
    • Carbetocin (100 ug - IM/IV)
    • Misoprostol (400 g or 600 g, per-oral)
    • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 ug - IM/IV)
    • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU,500g - IM)
  • Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent (drug of choice) for AMTSL.

 

Educational Objective:


The recommended dose of carbetocin for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage is 100 mcg, administered either IM or IV.

questions.text: The commonest indication for liver transplantation in children is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliary atresia

 

Liver transplantation is a crucial life-saving procedure for children with liver failure. The most common indication for liver transplantation in children is biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is a condition characterized by a blockage in the bile ducts outside the liver, leading to progressive liver damage and cirrhosis.

 

For infants diagnosed with biliary atresia, a surgical procedure known as hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure) is performed to establish bile drainage. However, if the Kasai procedure is not successful in restoring bile flow, liver transplantation becomes necessary, often within the first year of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alagille syndrome: This syndrome, characterized by butterfly-shaped vertebrae and congenital heart disease (often pulmonary stenosis), results in infantile cholestasis due to a syndromic paucity of intralobular bile ducts. It is a less common indication for liver transplantation compared to biliary atresia.

 

Option C. Caroli disease: This is a rare congenital disorder characterized by dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. While it can lead to liver failure, it is not the most common indication for liver transplantation in children.

 

Option D. Hepatocellular carcinoma: This is a rare cause of liver transplantation in children. While liver tumors can necessitate transplantation, they are less common compared to biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children due to the progressive liver damage and cirrhosis caused by bile duct obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a bone marrow aspirate having the finding as shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic myeloid leukemia

 

The image shows a characteristic cell known as a Gaucher cell, identifiable by its distinctive "crumpled tissue paper" or "wrinkled" cytoplasm appearance and blue staining.

 

 

Gaucher cells are lipid-laden histiocytes seen in Gaucher disease, but similar cells, called pseudo-Gaucher cells, can also be found in hematological malignancies, particularly in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). In CML, the presence of pseudo-Gaucher cells is a response to increased cellular turnover and abnormal lipid metabolism, making this finding more associated with CML than with other forms of leukemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute myeloid leukemia: While AML may show abnormal blast cells in the bone marrow, it is not typically associated with Gaucher or pseudo-Gaucher cells.

 

Option B. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia: ALL is characterized by lymphoblasts and does not typically present with pseudo-Gaucher cells in the bone marrow.

 

Option D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia: CLL involves mature lymphocytes, and pseudo-Gaucher cells are not a typical finding in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudo-Gaucher cells, characterized by a crumpled cytoplasm appearance, are often seen in chronic myeloid leukemia due to increased cellular turnover and abnormal lipid metabolism

questions.text: A 37-year-old female complains of recurrent episodes of discomfort, pain, and a sensation of pressure behind her left eye. She has intermittent proptosis that is reducible. Her symptoms and signs are accentuated when she bends forward. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital varices

 

Explanation:

 

Orbital varices are dilated venous channels in the orbit that can cause intermittent proptosis, which becomes more pronounced with maneuvers that increase venous pressure such as bending forward, straining, or performing a Valsalva maneuver. This intermittent and reducible nature of the proptosis is a key feature distinguishing orbital varices from other conditions.

 

Additional Information –

 

Three types of vascular malformations of the orbit:

 

Type 1 Vascular Malformation (Lymphangioma of the Orbit): This is characterized by no flow and is specifically referred to as lymphangioma of the orbit.

 

Type 2 Vascular Malformation (Orbital Varices): These are identified by having venous flow. Orbital varices typically result in intermittent proptosis, which is particularly exacerbated when the patient is straining, such as during violent coughing, Valsalva maneuvers, or bending forward.

 

Type 3 Vascular Malformation (Arterial or Arteriovenous Flow): This type involves arterial or arteriovenous flow, with orbital arteriovenous (AV) malformations being a classic example.

 

Among these, orbital varices (Type 2) are unique, as they cause intermittent proptosis exacerbated by specific physical maneuvers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital hemangioma: This is the most common benign tumor of the orbit in adults but does not typically cause intermittent proptosis.

 

Option C. Orbital metastasis: Can cause proptosis but typically presents with persistent proptosis and often with associated signs like eyelid ecchymosis.

 

Option D. Orbital dermoid cyst: Can cause proptosis, but it is usually not intermittent and reducible as described in this case.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Intermittent and reducible proptosis, accentuated by straining or bending forward, is characteristic of orbital varices.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient arrives at the OPD with a concern about her ability to perceive speech sounds while struggling to comprehend the actual words being spoken. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results show discrepancies, as the PTA is relatively within the normal range. However, her mid-latency and cortical responses are both non-existent. What probable diagnosis can be inferred from these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auditory neuropathy

 

If a child arrives with concerns about not being able to comprehend words, and their BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) results are abnormal while their PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry) results are normal, this could indicate the presence of auditory neuropathy.

 

Auditory neuropathy is a neurologic disorder of CN VIII. Audiometric tests, e.g. SNHL for pure tones, impaired speech discrimination score, absent or abnormal auditory brainstem response, show a retrocochlear type of lesion but OAEs are normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Michel aplasia also known as complete labyrinthine aplasia, is the most severe congenital inner ear malformation, characterized by complete absence of inner ear structures. This condition would present with profound hearing loss detected on PTA, not normal PTA results.

 

Option C. Malingering: Intentional falsification of hearing loss would likely be exposed by objective tests like BERA, which would not show the abnormal results observed in this case.

 

Option D. Cochlear otosclerosis shows Carhart’s notch (dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction) on PTA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory neuropathy should be suspected in patients who present with normal hearing sensitivity on pure tone audiometry but show significant difficulties with speech comprehension and abnormal brainstem evoked response audiometry results.

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the most appropriate management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ART immediately and continue life long

 

Explanation:

 

The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) recommends that all pregnant women with HIV should start antiretroviral therapy (ART) immediately, regardless of the stage of their disease or their CD4 count. This approach is aimed at reducing the viral load as quickly as possible, thereby decreasing the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV. ART should be continued lifelong to ensure ongoing viral suppression and the health of the mother.

 

Management of HIV-positive pregnancy includes:

 

  1. Antenatal care:
    • Testing for other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), CMV, toxoplasmosis, tuberculosis, fungal, and other opportunistic infections.
    • Partner/husband should also be tested.
    • To prevent pneumocystis pneumonia, start co-trimoxazole if CD4 count is ≤ 250 cells/mm³ and continue through pregnancy, delivery, and breastfeeding (dose: double strength tablet, 1 tablet daily).
    • Assess immunization status and update as needed.
    • Counseling on the impact of HIV on pregnancy and factors influencing the progression of the disease and risk of perinatal transmission.
    • CD4 count testing in each trimester.
    • Monitor HIV RNA levels monthly after changing/initiating therapy.
    • CBC, LFT, and KFT in each trimester.
  2. Anti-retroviral therapy for all:
    • As per NACO: Start ART at diagnosis (regardless of CD4 count); continue lifelong.
    • Initiate lifelong ART in all pregnant women with confirmed HIV infection regardless of WHO clinical stage or CD4 cell count.
    • TDF + 3TC + EFV is recommended as first-line ART in pregnant and breastfeeding women (including pregnant women in the first trimester of pregnancy).
    • Pregnant women detected to be HIV-positive for the first time in labor should be initiated on ART (TDF + 3TC + EFV) immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Start ART immediately upon diagnosis of HIV in pregnancy and continue lifelong to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission and maintain the health of the mother.

questions.text: Which part of this bone is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. B

 

The coracoid process is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa and is marked on the scapula as B. The coracoid process's tip is located approximately 2.5 cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). As a result, the coracoid process can be palpated below the clavicle.

 

The coracoid process arises from the upper border of the neck of the scapula and it projects forwards and slightly laterally. Attachments at the coracoid process include

 

  • The conoid portion of the coracoclavicular ligament
  • Pectoralis minor
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament
  • Glenocorocoidligamnet
  • Coracobrachialis muscle
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament
  • Glenocorocoidligamnet
  • Coracobrachialis muscle

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromian process continues from the spine of the scapula. The acromion is subcutaneous over its dorsal surface, The attachments at the acromion are the coracoacromial ligament, the articular capsule of the acromioclavicular joint, and horizontal fibers of the trapezius.

 

Option C. The glenoid fossa is present at the lateral angle of the scapula. It is articular with the humerus to form the shoulder joint.

 

Option D. The inferior angle lies over the seventh rib. Dorsally, it is related to latissimus dorsi. The angle is visible when the arm is raised over the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The coracoid process is a palpable landmark in the infraclavicular fossa, important for clinical examination and as a reference point for various shoulder procedures. Its recognition is crucial in the assessment of shoulder pathologies and for orientation during surgical approaches to the shoulder.

choices.text: Below pubic symphysis
Above pubic symphysis
Below umbilicus
Above umbilicus

questions.text: What is the true statement regarding level of uterus just after delivery? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Below umbilicus

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Below pubic symphysis: This is not accurate immediately after delivery as the uterus is still quite large and palpable above the pubic symphysis.

 

Option B. Above pubic symphysis: While this is true in a general sense postpartum, it is not specific enough to accurately describe the position immediately after delivery.

 

Option D. Above umbilicus: This is incorrect because the uterus immediately after delivery is positioned at the lower border of the umbilicus, not above it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediately after delivery, the uterus is positioned at the lower border of the umbilicus, equivalent to the size it would be at 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: D. C. Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 170

choices.text: It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh
A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication
Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy experienced symptoms of a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a slight fever. Upon examination, the presented clinical image is visible. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication

 

A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication: This is false. A prior adverse reaction with a temperature above 40 degrees Celsius is a contraindication, not 37 degrees Celsius. Minor reactions, such as a mild fever, are not typically considered a contraindication for future vaccinations.

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A.  It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh: This is true. The DPT vaccine is typically administered intramuscularly on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh in infants and young children.

 

Option C. Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age: This is true. The whole-cell pertussis vaccine is generally not recommended for individuals over the age of 7 due to an increased risk of adverse reactions. Instead, the acellular pertussis vaccine is used in older children and adults.

 

Option D. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose: This is true. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is lower than in pediatric formulations to reduce the risk of adverse reactions while still providing adequate immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What does the zero pressure indicate in the pressure-volume curve? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

The pressure-volume curve represents the relationship between the lung volumes and the transpulmonary pressures. Zero pressure in this context usually refers to the point where the pressure inside the lungs is equal to the atmospheric pressure, indicating a state of no net airflow. This point corresponds to the functional residual capacity (FRC), which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation.

 

  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC): It is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. This capacity includes the expiratory reserve volume (ERV) and the residual volume (RV). FRC is an important measure because it represents the balance point between the elastic recoil forces of the lungs and the chest wall.

 

 

The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. The normal value is about 2.5 liters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Residual volume is the air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort.

 

Option C: Tidal volume is the amount of air that moves in during each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration, during quiet breathing.

 

Option D: Inspiratory reserve volume is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in addition to the tidal volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zero pressure in the pressure-volume curve indicates the functional residual capacity, which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of intermenstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria gonorrhoea

 

The history of multiple sexual partners and lower abdominal pain with discharge and intermenstrual bleed suggests a diagnosis of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, of which cause can be N. Gonorrhoea among the given options.

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

 

 

Treatment –

 

KIT 6 (Yellow) – Tab Cefixime 400mg 1 Tab

 

  • Tab Metronidazole 400 mg (1 tab BD x 1 days)
  •  Tab Doxycycline 100 mg (1 tab BD x 21 days)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex causes painful genital ulcers.

 

Option B. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis is seen in sexually inactive females

 

Option C. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents as intense pruritus and white discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections, with Neisseria gonorrhoeae being a major pathogen, especially in women with multiple sexual partners presenting with lower abdominal pain and intermenstrual bleeding.

questions.text:
What is utilized to establish dependence among the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)

  1. Strong desire to use the drug
  2. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity
  3. Increased tolerance
  4. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

questions.text:
A woman diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome has undergone a renal biopsy. All of the following statement(s) is/are true except? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. FSGS is not diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy.
  2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy.
  3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma.
  4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement should undergo renal biopsy.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

After an open or needle biopsy, patient will be kept in a recovery or an observation unit for 24 hours to monitor for potential complications, including pain and bleeding.

 

Bleeding and hematoma are the common complication of kidney biopsy. Patient can complain of blood or dark red clots in urine.

 

Statement 1. FSGS is not diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is diagnosed by biopsy for which a tissue sample is obtained by an invasive technique (percutaneous renal biopsy).

 

It's named "focal" because only some glomeruli are affected, and "segmental" because only parts of each glomerulus are affected, so biopsy is essential to catch it.

 

Statement 4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement should undergo renal biopsy: Renal venules are not affected in renal involvement in systemic amyloidosis. While a renal biopsy can confirm renal amyloid deposition, less invasive sites (like abdominal fat pad aspirate, rectal mucosa, or gingival biopsy) are often preferred first. Most commonly Abdominal fat pad biopsy is done.

 

Other Options

 

Statement 2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy: After a renal biopsy, the patient should indeed be observed for 24 hours to monitor for potential complications like pain and bleeding.

 

Statement 3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma: The presence of dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy is indicative of a hematoma, which is a common complication post-biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous renal biopsy is a key diagnostic tool for conditions like FSGS, and proper post-procedure monitoring is essential to manage potential complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old brought to the emergency department with complaints of mild bloody rhinorrhea. On examination, he was awake and oriented. Drainage has soiled his shirt, and the appearance of which is given below. This is seen in case of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Traumatic CSF Rhinorrhea

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with mild bloody rhinorrhea, and the drainage has created a characteristic "halo sign" or "double ring sign" on his shirt. This sign indicates the presence of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) mixed with blood. The halo sign is seen when CSF forms a clear ring around a central bloody spot on absorbent material. This finding is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where trauma causes a breach in the meninges, allowing CSF to leak and mix with nasal secretions or blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spontaneous CSF Rhinorrhea: Spontaneous CSF rhinorrhea typically involves clear CSF leakage without blood. The absence of blood would not produce the halo sign as described.

 

Option C. Meningocele: Meningocele involves herniation of the meninges through a defect in the skull or spinal column but does not typically cause nasal CSF leakage mixed with blood. It usually presents as a mass or bulge.

 

Option D. Tumors: Tumors might cause nasal discharge, but the presence of a halo sign specifically points to a CSF leak, which is more characteristic of traumatic causes rather than tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The halo sign or double ring sign on absorbent material is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where CSF leaks and mixes with blood, creating a central red spot surrounded by a clear or yellowish ring.

choices.text: Platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 (PECAM-1)

questions.text: Which of the following molecules are involved in helping the leukocytes to roll over the endothelial cells in the vessels? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E-selectin

 

E-selectins are involved in rolling of leucocytes over endothelial cells.

 

Cellular Changes during Inflammation

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cadherins: These are involved in cell-cell adhesion in various tissues but are not specifically involved in the rolling of leukocytes during inflammation.

 

Option B. PECAM-1 (Platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1): PECAM-1 is primarily involved in the process of diapedesis, where leukocytes transmigrate across the endothelium.

 

Option D. CD11a: This is an integrin (part of the LFA-1 complex) involved in the firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium, not in the rolling process.

 

Educational Objective:


E-selectin is critical for the rolling of leukocytes along the endothelial cells during the early stages of the inflammatory response.
